bestBHT.bht: The husbandmen in this story displayed great cruelty towards the owner's servants. They beat, killed, and stoned them, reflecting the history of maltreatment suffered by God's messengers. The refusal to honor the son showed their deep-seated malice. Despite God's attempts to correct them through prophets, their obstinate cruelty prevailed. They seized and abused the servants violently, preventing them from fulfilling their duties. The abhorrent methods of killing used by the husbandmen served to highlight the wickedness of their actions.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: And the husbandmen took his servants, and beat one—see Jeremiah 37:15; Jeremiah 38:6.
John Calvin: Hence it appears how obstinate their malice was, for the correction of which no remedies were of any avail.
That God did not, on account of the cruelty of the priests, fail to send prophets; but raising them up — as it were — in troops, fought against their malice.
Since all the means and remedies which God employed for it were of no avail.
Philip Schaff: The maltreatment of the servants appears in the history of the prophets.
God’s messengers have often suffered since at the hands of the official personages in the external Church.
The maltreatment of the servants... comp. Nehemiah 9:26; Matthew 23:29-31; Matthew 23:34; Matthew 23:37; 1 Thessalonians 2:15; Hebrews 11:36-38; Revelation 16:6; Revelation 18:24.
Archibald T. Robertson: It is the picture of turning with respect when one worthy of it appears.
John Gill: They seized and laid hold of them in a rude and violent manner... so far from delivering to them the fruit due to their master."
They cut off the person's head with a sword... there is no death more abominable than this."
They stoned them... and shamefully handled, and sadly abused.

bhtAttempts.bht: The passage tells the story of the husbandmen who mistreated and even killed the servants sent by the owner of the vineyard. This is an echo of the maltreatment of God's messengers throughout history, as seen in the history of the prophets. Their refusal to reverence the son highlights their deep-seated obstinate malice. Despite God's efforts to send prophets and correct their ways, their cruelty prevailed. The husbandmen seized and laid hold of the servants in a violent and rude manner, leaving no room for delivering the fruit due to their master. Their method of killing, whether beating, beheading, or stoning, demonstrated the abominable nature of their actions.

The husbandmen in this verse took the owner's servants and treated them mercilessly, even killing and stoning them. Their refusal to respect the son reflects their deep-seated maliciousness. The maltreatment of the servants echoes the history of prophets who suffered at the hands of the religious leaders. Despite God's attempts to correct them, their obstinate cruelty prevailed. The violent and rude manner in which they seized and abused the servants left no opportunity for delivering the fruit due to the master. The abhorrent methods they used to kill the servants further highlight their wickedness.

The husbandmen mistreated the owner's servants, beating, killing, and stoning them. Their refusal to honor the son reveals their deep-seated malice. This mirrors the historical maltreatment of God's messengers and prophets by religious officials. Despite God's efforts to correct them, their obstinate cruelty persisted. The violent and rude manner in which they seized and abused the servants prevented them from fulfilling their duties. Their barbaric methods of killing only emphasized the wickedness of their actions.

The husbandmen took the owner's servants and mercilessly beat, killed, and stoned them. This reflects the history of maltreatment of God's messengers by religious officials. The refusal to reverence the son reveals a deep-seated obstinate malice. Despite God's efforts to correct their ways through prophets, their cruelty prevailed. They seized and abused the servants in a violent and rude manner, preventing them from fulfilling their duties. Their abominable methods of killing further emphasize the heinous nature of their actions.

The husbandmen in this story displayed great cruelty towards the owner's servants. They beat, killed, and stoned them, reflecting the history of maltreatment suffered by God's messengers. The refusal to honor the son showed their deep-seated malice. Despite God's attempts to correct them through prophets, their obstinate cruelty prevailed. They seized and abused the servants violently, preventing them from fulfilling their duties. The abhorrent methods of killing used by the husbandmen served to highlight the wickedness of their actions.
